Among all molecular sieves, mesoporous materials with high surface area and pore volume, tuneable pore sizes, and rich morphology can serve as both efficient catalytic supports and catalysts. The modification of meso‑pores with transition metal species provides the materials with great properties, making the catalysis process highly selective and controllable. This emerging area can provide researchers with great opportunity to introduce novel heterogeneous catalysts from both industrial and environmentally friendly viewpoints. Keywords Benzene Phenol Hydroxylation Selective oxidation Mesoporous materials 1 Introduction Phenol is one of the most valuable chemical products, plays an important role in resin, fiber, medicine, dyestuffs and caprolactam industries [1-4]. Commercially, a large amount of phenol is produced via conventional three-step cumene process reported at 1994; which are as follows: (1) production of cumene through the alkylation of benzene with propylene in the presence of an acid catalyst; (2) conversion of cumene to cumene hydroperoxide by various oxidants and (3) hydrolysis of cumene hydroperoxide. The cumene method suffers from various drawbacks including generation of acetone in an equimolar amount as a by-product, high energy consumption, low efficiency [5, 6]. To address this matter, proposing direct and selective strategies of hydroxylation of benzene to phenol as an alternative path of well-known cumene process has been received remarkable attention [7, 8]. Moreover, from the point of view of green chemistry and chemical industry, one of the challenging goals is the selective catalytic oxidation of organic compounds using environmentally friendly and cheap oxidants as well as a heterogeneous, cost-effective and easily recyclable catalyst [9-15]. Since the invention of mesoporous materials researchers have given considerable attention to them, because these materials possess larger pores in contrast with microporous molecular sieves, allowing faster diffusion and processing of bulky molecules [16-20], so they have high potential use as adsorbents, heterogeneous catalysts, catalytic supports, and hosts for inclusion compounds [21-26]. Among the oxidants applied for the DHBP process, oxygen was used in order to oxidize the benzene to phenol with remarkable selectivity. Furthermore, oxygen is an extremely available reagent, nevertheless in the presence of such catalytic system; high reaction temperature is inevitably demanded [27-30]. Although N2O can provide high selectivity close to 100%, it cannot be industrially used because of its high cost [31, 32]. Consequently, H2O2 with the low cost and environmentally friendly characteristics, has been attracted numerous attentions as the oxidant in one-step benzene hydroxylation reactions [33-35]. Catalyst separation and product purification are the most challenging goals, imposing restrictions on homogenous catalytic systems. One of the suggested ways to solve these problems is to immobilize homogeneous catalysts on a solid matrix. It is expected that some advantages like promoting the catalytic activity, catalyst stability, product selectivity, and easy reusability will be achieved by immobilization of catalyst on the solid supports[36, 37]. In the past decade, an extensive range of transition metal-based catalyst systems immobilized on both silica and non-silica mesoporous supports have been reported for the direct benzene hydroxylation [11, 38]. Industrially, titanium silicalite-1 (TS-1) is a viable catalyst for the hydroxylation of benzene by incorporating of active species such as metal cations, anions or metal complexes[2, 39], while β-zeolite and MCM-22™ catalysts were commercially used for three-step cumene process [6]. Introduction of transition metals including V, Fe, Ru, Cu, Ti, Cr and Co into the silicate framework of mesoporous materials as well as encapsulation of their complexes inside the pores of mesoporous sieves generate new redox and acidic functionalities which are favorable in efficient catalytic performance including conversion of benzene to phenol [36, 40-50]. Furthermore, some noble metals including Pt and pd can be regarded as active sites for catalyzing benzene hydroxylation [20] and were introduced into the mesoporous support which are not considered in the present study [51-53]. One of the most important issues in an introduction of suitable catalysts for DHBP is that the one-step process suffers from the appropriate selectivity as well as the more tendency of phenol to oxidation versus benzene [54-58]. In this review, we focus on the applicability of various transition metal-based mesoporous materials as the catalysts in the DHBP process using different oxidants. 2 Supported vanadium-based catalysts Due to outstanding stability, highly feasible reactivity, high redox ability and intrinsic capacity towards hydrocarbon oxidation, vanadium species have been extensively employed as efficient catalysts for DHBP. 2.1 Vanadium−MCM supported heterogeneous catalysts A series of vanadium-based V-MCM-41 molecular sieves support with different Si/V ratios (from 20 to 200) were used in the selective DHBP by Chatterjee et al. (1999). The catalysts have been prepared via a hydrothermal route at room temperature without using the phase stabilizer and in the presence of the minimum amounts of the template. The studies on the geometry of vanadium centers in the both as- synthesized (non-calcined) and calcined V-MCM41 frameworks exhibited the presence of VO2+ with the square pyramidal and V5+ ion with the tetrahedral coordination geometries respectively, indicating the oxidation of VO2+to V5+ ion after calcination. The V + 5 tetrahedral active sites of calcined species, responsible for the hydroxylation of benzene, displayed a higher catalytic activity even than the vanadium-containing zeolite catalysts [59]. In the presence of H2O2 as the oxidant the catalytic property of V-MCM-41 and V-MCM-48 with microporous V-containing molecular sieves such as VS-1 and V-BET were compared by Lee and coworkers (2000). Owing to their large pore sizes, high surface area, and greater amount of vanadium species, V-MCM41 catalysts showed better catalytic property than did V-MCM48 and microporous materials under analogous conditions. The catalytic activity of V-MCM41 was found to increase with increase in temperature and acidic conditions. However, at 353 K, due to the decomposition of H2O2, a significant decrease in benzene conversion was observed [60]. The catalytic transformation of benzene to phenol using vanadium oxides (VOx) supported on MCM-41 and MCM-48 like structures, silica-based Aerosil® 300 type and amorphous siliceous microporous mixed oxides (AMM) systems in the presence of different solvents as the reaction media have been studied by Lemke et Al. (2003). The MCM-41 and MCM-48 frameworks were prepared using different methods including impregnation, direct hydrothermal and Schotten–Baumann reaction. The results are listed as below: 1 The VOx/MCM41 (1.1% w/v) prepared by the impregnation method displayed a higher selectivity than VOx/MCM48 catalyst. This can be attributed to the higher surface area pores of VOx/MCM41 versus VOx/MCM48. 2 The desorption of phenol from the catalyst is an important key factor in the reaction yield. Since, among all these three heterogeneous catalysts types, the Aerosil type with the lack of internal pore system, provides an easy desorption of phenol, leading to the best efficiency (75%) even at the low amounts of vanadium oxides contents on the support (VOx/SiO2, 0.14 w/v). Moreover, lower vanadium content can provide higher phenol selectivity. Besides, lower vanadium content can provide higher phenol selectivity because of better isolated vanadium sites that can restrain over oxidation of phenol to consecutive products [61]. Fig. 1 To incorporate the great content of vanadyl ions (VO)2+, Lee et al. (2003) used 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (APTS) to functionalize the surface of mesoporous silica of MCM-41 and silica gel (MCM41-NH2-(VO) and silica gel-NH2-(VO)). Fig. 2 The potentiality of prepared catalytic materials in the DHBP by H2O2 and TBHP as oxidant was compared with that of V-MCM-41. The vanadium peroxo complex of [V5+-O-O]˙ radicals play a key role in the DHBP. Since overoxidation of phenol has been suppressed in silica gel-NH2-(VO) catalyst due to less tendency of phenol toward reentry into silica gel, MCM41-NH2-(VO) showed higher conversion rate, but lower selectivity in comparison with silica gel-NH2-(VO). In addition, the results indicated that these anchored vanadium complexes are superior to that V-MCM41 in terms of phenol selectivity, conversion rate, and metal leaching. Furthermore, it was found that functionalization can provide some advantages including better isolation of catalytic sites as well as well control of available active sites by tuning the density of functionalization [62]. In order to investigate the influence of the incorporation of two different heteroatoms on redox and acidic properties of silica matrix, Parvulescu and coworkers (2003) prepared highly ordered hexagonal mesoporous MCM-41 materials incorporated by single (V and Nb) or bimetal (Nb–Ti and V–Ti) ions using hydrothermal procedure in the presence of two various silica sources (TEOS and sodium silicate). For benzene hydroxylation using H2O2 during 48 h reaction time at 343 K, V-containing catalysts are more efficient than Nb ones and V-MCM-41 derived from TEOS exhibited higher benzene conversion than the corresponding one synthesized with sodium silicate (67.3% and 62.2% respectively). After the introduction of Ti species, VTi-MCM-41 produced with sodium silicate showed benzene conversion of 78.2%, superior to all designed samples [63]. Lee et al. (2007) utilized different pore sizes of aluminum-substituted mesoporous silica materials including AlMCM-41, AlMCM-48 and AlMAS-9 as the support for grafting vanadium oxide catalysts using molecular designed dispersion method (MDD) and VO(acac)2 (acac:acetylacetonate) as a precursor. The capability of prepared catalyst compounds was investigated in DBHP in the liquid phase by H2O2 as the oxidant. The VV center with six coordination places was appeared when by hydrogen bonding or a ligand-exchange mechanism a monolayer deposition of VO(acac)2 complexes with square pyramidal coordination has occurred and then at an oxygen atmosphere and 580 °C, organic acac ligands were decomposed. (Fig. 3 ). The authors found that mobile ligands (i.e., H2O or solvent) around the catalytic center play an important role in catalytic activity. One mobile ligand was observed in the square pyramidal coordination, while the octahedral geometry of VV has two mobile ligands which can be easily substituted by H2O2 to provide active peroxo intermediate for the DHBP. benzene. As a result, the MCM-41-, MCM-48-, and MAS-9-VOx catalysts exhibited a modest increase in the catalytic activity than MCM-41-, MCM-48-, and MAS-9-VO(acac)2, arising from the fact that more mobile ligands which enhance the formation of active intermediates can be provided when VV centers present in a distorted octahedral coordination than in the square pyramidal. Moreover, a one-step and effective procedure for preparing the highly reactive VV centers was introduced and these catalysts showed better activity than those synthesized by previously multi-step route. Among all these catalysts, MAS-9-VOx synthesized through this convenient method, due to its larger pore size, showed the best catalytic activity with 7.08 TON and 82% of phenol selectivity [64]. Vanadium incorporated MCM-41 nanospheres synthesized via two different methods, impregnation and sol-gel, with varying spherical diameters (40–160 nm) were prepared by Zhao et al. (2014) to investigate the selective liquid phase hydroxylation of benzene to phenol in the presence of H2O2 as the oxidant. The catalyst with 40 nm diameter of support showed a better catalytic activity than that with 160 nm of particle size because small particle size easily facilitates the diffusion of the reagent and product molecules. Besides, in the same reaction conditions, the catalytic property of V-MCM41 prepared by sol-gel procedure was higher than that of synthesized via impregnation demonstrating that the vanadium species are the main active sites. As the vanadium content continued to raise, there was an outstanding increase in the benzene conversion, and reached 9.8% at 5.0% V/Si ratio with 100% phenol selectivity. However, due to channel blocking, an overloading of vanadium species has negative impact on the morphology and catalytic activity of the samples [65]. Yang et al. (2015) compared the capabilities of V-MCM-41 prepared by their proposed method, direct templating assembly, with previously reported post-synthesized route in liquid phase DHBP in the presence of hydrogen peroxide in acetonitrile (ACN) medium. In the case of directly synthesized catalyst, higher loading of vanadium content brings about a significant increase of benzene conversion associated with increasing more accessible active sites on the surface of the catalyst, owing to raising coverage of VO species on the MCM-41 pore walls affording maximum amount of 29.1% benzene conversion with 90% phenol selectivity over 11.13% V/Si ratio. Moreover, since directly synthesized heterogeneous catalyst possesses significantly higher number of vanadium active sites which were highly dispersed, corresponding post-synthesized sample exhibited poorer catalytic performance. In addition, stronger interaction of vanadium oxide species with the pore walls of the MCM-41 as well as decreasing contact between water and the silicate walls in the reaction system owing to increasing pore wall thickness arised from high vanadium species surface coverage on the pore walls may contribute to superior stability of directly synthesized samples compared to post-synthesized ones [66]. 2.2 Vanadium−SBA supported heterogeneous catalysts DHBP using molecular O2 and ascorbic acid as the reductant agent over bimetallic VOx/CuSBA-15 catalyst was carried out by Gu et al. (2007). VOx/CuSBA-15 catalyst not only can selectively catalyze DHBP but also can selectively activate dioxygen molecules rather than H2O2 on account of the presence of copper oxide species. In addition, vanadium-copper oxide supported on SBA-15 catalyst is more active than supported on MCM-41. This can be attributed to instant pore blocking during the impregnation procedure caused by smaller pore size of MCM-41 in comparison with SBA-15. Moreover, the result of DHBP using various transition metal oxides including Fe/Co/Ni/Cr/Mn/Zn and Ag together with VOx supported on SBA-15 demonstrated that the VOx/CuSBA-15 gave the highest catalytic activity (24.7% yield of phenol) in contrast with the others, which suggests a possible synergism between Cu and VOx species on the support. Rate determination step is the formation of hydroxyl radical through the activation of molecular oxygen [27]. Khatri and coworkers (2011) compared the catalytic activity of oxo-vanadium Schiff bases immobilizing on chlorotriphosphazenyl anchored 3-amino-functionalized SBA-15 and homogeneous silica immobilized oxo-vanadium Schiff base in the DHBP with H2O2 as an oxidant. Higher benzene conversion of 30.8 with 100% phenol selectivity was reported in acetonitrile at 50 °C for 8 h reaction time in the case of cyclotriphosphazene grafted mesoporous silica immobilized oxo-vanadium Schiff base. As shown in Fig. 4 , it can be attributed to the cyclotriphosphazene with the cyclic structure which can provide the existence of multiple reactive oxo-vanadium species in the close neighborhood [67]. Hu et al. (2014) compared the catalytic activity of silylated V/DMDS-x/SBA-15 catalysts providing by post-grafting of dimethyldichlorosilane (DMDS) onto SBA-15 with various silylation degree (0.5–2.0) with non- silylated one in DHBP with H2O2 as the oxidant and acetic acid as the solvent. Benzene conversion as well as phenol yield increase with increasing silylation degree reaching the maximum amount of 34.1% and 31.7% respectively over V/DMDS-1.0/SBA-15 catalyst, but a slight decrease in phenol selectivity was reported. Enhancement in catalytic performance can be attributed to the fact that increasing the silylation degree of catalyst provides hydrophobic property for catalyst's surface leading to increase of benzene adsorption, a non-polar molecule, along with the decrease of H2O2 activation due to it's hydrophilic nature. Moreover, since phenol can be quickly desorbed and diffused over the silylated samples than the non-silylated one, consecutive oxidation reaction were suppressed on non-silylated catalysts causing higher phenol selectivity than silylated materials [68]. In 2008, SBA-16 with well-defined pore size, three-dimensional channels, high thermal stability cubic cage-like pore structure was used as support for incorporating the vanadium oxide (VOx/SBA-16) using the impregnation method. Different vanadium content, from 1.7% to 9.1%, were examined in the liquid phase DHBP using of H2O2 as the oxidant. It was observed that V loading had a significant impact on the TON and yield of phenol reaching the maximum one when the amount of V loading was 7.3 wt%, and then a modest reduction was appeared with the further increase in the amount of V loading, whereas the selectivity to phenol decreased marginally. Raman and XRD studies showed that the molecular structure of the vanadia species located at the surface at low vanadium content was tetrahedral VO4 species, while 7.3% VOx/SBA-16 possesses both polymerized VO4 units and nanostructured microcrystallites of V2O5 leading to the increase in catalytic property but its phenol selectivity decreases. [69]. DHBP in the presence of molecular O2 as the oxidant and ascorbic acid as the reductant agent over V-SBA-16 prepared by direct hydrothermal method in various pH from 0.5 to 2.5 was reported by Zhao et al. (2012). The authors found that the V content, conservation of highly-ordered mesoporous structure and the integration of V into the SBA-16 network are sensitive to the pH of the initial gel during the synthesis of V-SBA-16. With increasing the pH, the vanadium content also increases and a relative high V content of 1.60 wt% was obtained for the VS-2.5(1.60) sample. In order to suppress the transformation of isolated tetrahedral VO4 to agglomerated V2O5 crystallites, obtain well-ordered mesoporous structure, and enhance vanadium dispersion V-SBA-16 materials should be synthesized in pH 2.0. This catalyst with 1.67% wt of vanadium content and highly dispersed vanadium species gave 90% phenol selectivity and yield of 30.4% [70]. 2.3 Vanadium−HMS supported heterogeneous catalysts In 2009, Feng et al. selected hexagonal mesoporous silica (HMS) in order to incorporate of transition metal vanadium by co-synthesis method using dodecylamine (DDA) as template. The catalytic properties of prepared V-HMS catalysts with various vanadium contents (1.81–14) for DHBP using hydrogen peroxide as an oxidant were studied. The impacts of different catalytic factors including vanadium content, amount of H2O2 and reaction temperature were also investigated. In low vanadium content, VO4 species are tetrahedrally isolated, while increasing vanadium loading leading to low catalytic activity, which may be due to the aggregation of the isolated vanadium species. The results indicated that V-HMS catalyst with 6.21 vanadium contents can produce phenol with almost 11.1% yield and 85% benzene conversion [71]. Hu and coworkers reported the synthesis and catalytic properties of a series of mesoporous Cux-V-HMS catalysts in DHBP at 2014. The effect of different amount of copper (0.45–1.35) on catalytic activity of the prepared catalysts was also investigated. The results showed that by increasing the Cu concentration, the catalytic property was significantly increased, owing to the improvement of redox properties of V species and benzene adsorption ability of the catalysts. As a result, in comparison with V-HMS, Cux-VHMS exhibited higher catalytic performance. The Cu (0.90)–V-HMS exhibited outstanding catalytic activity (yield of 29.0%) and selectivity (92.2%) in conversion of benzene to phenol. Moreover, the high recyclability of the Cux–V-HMS catalysts (at least five times) established this fact that the stability and activity of the catalysts in DHBP are considerable [72]. 2.4 Vanadium−Mesoporous carbon heterogeneous catalysts In 2015, two dimensional (2D) hexagonal mesoporous carbon was employed as a support to introduce vanadium species using vanadyl acetylacetonate [VO(acac)2] as a metal source by the co-assembly technique and tested for DHBP with H2O2. At vanadium content of more than 0.2 g the benzene conversion decreased while the phenol selectivity remained almost constant associating with the deterioration of the ordered mesostructured. Moreover, it was found that calcination temperature had an important impact on dispersion state of V species, and 300 °C calcination temperature was the best one whereas with the further increase of temperature decreasing of active centers as well as the amount of •OH radicals were occurred resulting to gradual decrease of benzene conversion while the phenol selectivity increased slightly. Outstanding phenol selectivity of 94.9% with benzene conversion of 31.8% was obtained over 0.2-V-C-600 catalyst under the investigated conditions. The nanocrystals of vanadium formed at 600 °C which are mainly confined in the carbon matrix may play a key role in better catalytic reusability of 0.2-V-C-600 compared to 0.2-V-C-300 [73]. In order to enhance their previous work by way of developing the carbon framework, Hu and coworkers (2016) using well-ordered, three-dimensional (3D) nitrogen doped mesoporous carbon (NC) as a support for introduction of vanadium species. The designed heterogeneous catalysts were examined in the DHBP reaction with H2O2 as an oxidant in the presence of acetic acid. It was found that their catalytic properties depend on the calcination temperature and V content. The better catalytic activity of the benzene conversion of 31.0%, and phenol selectivity of 97.2% were obtained over 4.2% vanadium content as well as calcination temperature of 600 °C (4.2 V/NC-600). Besides, to explore the influence of the nitrogen doped mesoporous carbon support on the catalytic performance, the vanadium containing 2D hexagonal mesoporous carbon with nitrogen doped (V content: 4.2%) were tested (4.2 V/C-hexa) under the same reaction conditions and showed lower catalytic performance. Besides the vanadium species, highly ordered 3D mesostructured of NC support facilitating reactants diffusion along with open – conjugated system which enhances benzene adsorption and activation are the main reasons why 4.2 V/NC-600 catalyst displayed the best catalytic activity (Fig. 5 ) [74]. The catalytic activity of vanadium incorporated into three-dimensional (3D) ordered body-centered cubic mesoporous carbon catalysts prepared by two various methods, co-assembly(V-C-cubic) and impregnation (V/C-cubic), were compared with vanadium supported mesoporous carbon nanospheres derived from impregnation (V/MCN-S) in selective DHBP with H2O2 as the oxidant in acetic acid medium. Among all designed catalysts, V/MCN-S with 4 wt% vanadium content showed excellent activity with phenol yield and selectivity of 36.7% and 96.1% respectively which was superior to the catalysts previously reported by the authors. Carbon nanosphere provides not only high dispersion of vanadium nanoparticles but also easily accessible active centers for the reactants owing to its shorter channels indicating that textural properties of support play a crucial role in catalytic performance. The lower catalytic activity of V-C-cubic samples can be attributed to the lower exposure of active sites due to tightly embedded of vanadium species in carbon matrix. In case of V/C-cubic catalysts, the severe agglomeration and poor dispersion of vanadium species as well as the bulk structure of carbon support have negative impact on catalytic performance. The trend of catalytic activity of catalyst is as follows: V/MCN-S >V/C-cubic > V-C-cubic [75]. 2.5 Vanadium−MesoporousTiO2 heterogeneous catalysts Xu et al. (2012) reported liquid phase hydroxylation of benzene using H2O2 as the oxidant over a series of mesoporous TiO2-supported VOx (VOx/TiO2) catalysts with various range of vanadium loading (2.27–9.06) synthesized direct hydrothermal procedure. Based on the study of the effect of calcination temperature on the catalytic activity the highest yield of phenol was obtained at 550 C. At higher temperature on account of the complete transformation of anatase phase TiO2 to rutile phase TiO2 a dramatic decrease in catalytic performance was observed. In addition, with increasing in the vanadium loading more than 4.30 wt% because of the aggregation of VOx components and easy formation of a VxTi1-xO2 rutile-phase solid-solution with TiO2, a slight decrease in phenol yield was reported. Hence, VOx/TiO2 calcined at 550 C with 4.30 wt% of vanadium and low rutile content (12.6 wt%) containing isolated, highly dispersed VOx with two valances, +4 and +5, exhibited excellent catalytic activity with a phenol yield of around 23.8% and phenol selectivity of about 85% [76]. Two years later, Xu and coworkers studied the selective hydroxylation of benzene to phenol over anchored Ag nanoparticles on VOx–TiO2 mesoporous material with different Ag content (0.29–4.2 wt%) using hydrothermal synthesis method. Ag/V (4.3)–TiO2 catalyst with 0.96 wt% Ag content prepared at 550 C calcination temperature showed higher catalytic performance compared to VOx–TiO2 catalyst reported in previous author's literature and the yield of phenol reached nearly 28% with 95% phenol selectivity. It was found that adding silver to the catalyst, VOx–TiO2, can provide some advantages in terms of catalysts and vanadium species including promotes redox ability, the reduction, and monodispersion of vanadium species on the surface of TiO2, and also effectively enhances the thermolability of the catalyst suggesting a synergism between VOx and Ag species [77]. 2.6 Vanadium−PMO supported heterogeneous catalysts Borah et al. (2012) successfully prepared a novel type of heterogeneous catalyst by immobilization of vanadyl (IV) acetylacetonate complex, [VO (acac)2], on to periodic mesoporous silica (PMO) for the selective hydroxylation of benzene to phenol with hydrogen peroxide as the oxidant and acetonitrile as the solvent. By employing [VO (acac)2]-grafted PMO catalyst, selectivity of 100% and a benzene conversion of over 27% in 8 h reaction, was observed, which was higher than homogenous [VO(acac)2] complex (76.9% selectivity) under the same reaction conditions. Formation of overoxidized products was hampered due to the fact that hydrogen bonded silanol groups on the framework of PMOs can act as Bronsted acidic sites; hence, weakly basic benzene can be easily adsorbed onto the acidic framework of the PMO catalysts, subsequently once benzene is converted into phenol, acidic phenol is desorbed immediately from the acidic framework. In addition, the authors proposed mechanism for the catalytic cycle was as follows: vanadyl (IV) is oxidized to a peroxo vanadyl radical (V5+-O-O.) in the presence of H2O2, afterwards the insertion of oxygen atom in one of the CH bonds of benzene and the regeneration of V4+ species has occurred. Fig. 6 . Moreover, the newly designed heterogeneous catalysts provide two advantages including both environmentally friendly and high selectivity toward the phenol product [78]. 2.7 Vanadium−Mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride heterogeneous catalysts In another report, to increase catalytic performance, Xu et al. utilized mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (g-CN) as a new support to immobilize vanadyl(IV) acetylacetonate ([VO(acac)2]). Due to the reaction between the carbonyl group of the acetylacetonate ligand and the terminal amine groups of g-CN, a Schiff-base-type vanadyl complex was formed. For liquid-phase H2O2 hydroxylation pf benzene to phenol, the activity of this newly designed heterogonous catalyst was higher than vanadyl complex grafted on amine functionalized SBA-15, and achieved catalytic conversion of benzene (20.7%) along with high selectivity (96.8%) to phenol. Moreover, the catalytic performance of this prepared catalysts are sensitive to grafting temperatures, and when the temperature raised to 120 C, the whole amounts of catalytically active species increase [79]. 2.8 Vanadium− mesoporous KIT-6 supported heterogeneous catalysts Amine-functionalized ordered mesoporous silica KIT-6 was used as support to immobilize vanadyl (IV) acetylacetonate [VO(acac)2] homogenous catalyst with various vanadium content via the Schiff base reaction by Xu and coworkers. The catalytic activity of the designed catalyst in the direct hydroxylation of benzene to phenol over H2O2 as an oxidant was compared with other two typical ordered mesoporous silicas including FDU-12-NH2 and SBA-15-NH2. KIT-6-NH2–1.9 V exhibited the highest catalytic performance with 17.4% conversion and more than 99% selectivity which was attributed to excellent benzene adsorption capacity[80]. 3 Supported Fe and Ru-based catalysts Other metals with reported applications in the DHBP are iron and ruthenium. 3.1 Ruthenium−FSM-16 supported heterogeneous catalysts Fujishima et al. (2001) studied photo oxidation of benzene to phenol over bis- and tris(bipyridine) Ru complexes grafted on mesoporous FSM-16 by impregnation method and using H2O2 as an oxidation reagent under UV–VIS irradiation. [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2/FSM-1 gave 98% phenol product selectively and the turn over number (TON) of 430 in 24 h. The impregnated catalyst exhibited a higher activity than non-grafted [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2 complexes demonstrating the effect of immobilization of catalyst on FSM-16 support on enhancing of catalytic activity. It can be attributed to the site isolation of active Ru species. Moreover, the authors found that the MC excitation of [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2 in UV–VIS irradiation via facilitating the production of OH radical remarkably increases hydroxylation of benzene to phenol [81]. 3.2 Ruthenium/Iron−MCM supported heterogeneous catalysts In order to study the effects of the second metal on catalytic activity, Parvulescu and coworkers (2004), who previously synthesized bimetal (Nb-Ti or V-Ti)-MCM-41 catalysts, using direct synthesis method to prepare bimetallic Ru-(Cr, Ni, Cu) and La-(Co or Mn) modified-MCM-41 molecular sieves. In liquid phase hydroxylation of benzene to phenol using H2O2 as an oxidant, bimetallic RuCr-MCM-41 and LaMn-MCM-41 exhibited higher catalytic activity of more than 60% benzene conversion than that of single metal incorporated Ru-MCM-41 and La-MCM-41, indicating that the activity and selectivity of bimetallic Ru-, La-MCM-41 catalysts depended on the presence of the second metal, and reaction conditions [82]. The catalytic performance of iron (III)−5,10,15,20-tetra-(4-pyridyl) porphyrin (Fe-TPyP) encapsulated in two different support Al-MCM-41 with Si/Al = 20 and Poly (methacrylic acid) (PMAA) in benzene hydroxylation in the presence of H2O2 as an oxidant was investigated by Nur et al. (2006). It was found that phenol yield of iron porphyrin encapsulated in PMAA was higher than that of Fe-TPyP encapsulated in Al-MCM-4, while the product selectivity and stability of Fe-TPyP–MCM-41 was superior, and achieved a phenol selectivity of 100%. This result can be attributed to the ordered structure of Fe-TPyP–MCM-41 catalyst as well as the hydrophobic nature of Fe-TPyP–PMAA [83]. Sirotin et al. (2009) studied liquid oxidation of benzene over Fe2O3 stabilized in the mesopores of an MCM-41 sieve by two introduction methods including during the synthesis and adsorption from solution at 75 C using H2O2 as the oxidant. Samples with the smaller amount of metal content showed the best catalytic activity since the MCM-41 structure remains almost intact and the metal oxides embedded in channel walls or localized on their surface are in a highly dispersed state and isolated from one another. Moreover, since pore blocking doesn't occur during the preparation of Fe2O3 −MCM41 catalyst via post synthetic, it displays higher catalytic activity than the samples prepared by iron introduction in the synthesis [84]. In 2015, the photocatalytic hydroxylation of benzene to phenol by cyano-bridged polynuclear metal complex containing FeII and RuII incorporated in spherical mesoporous silica-alumina ([Fe(H2O)3]2[Ru(CN)6]@sAl-MCM-41) by the combination of the catalytic hydroxylation of benzene to phenol with H2O2 and the photocatalytic production of H2O2 from H2O and O2 was investigated by Aratani and coworkers. This process involves two-step route; (1) Photocatalytic reduction of molecular oxygen to peroxide has been occurred in the presence of water as an electron donor, and then (2) the achieved peroxide is used as an oxidant for hydroxylation of benzene. Compared to, the cyano-bridged polynuclear metal complex, [Fe (H2O)3]2[Ru-(CN)6], with 393 TON in 60 h, incorporated [Fe(H2O)3]2[Ru(CN)6] in sAl-MCM-41indicted higher TON (2500) for 114 h. As a result, the authors may have introduced a new strategy for production of phenol from benzene in a one-step reaction with O2 as an oxidant as well as an ideal oxygen (Fig. 7 ) [85]. 3.3 Iron−SBA supported heterogeneous catalysts The DHBP process was performed at 623 K in the presence of He using iron-functionalized Al-SBA-15 with 1.63 and 0.21 wt.% Fe content and nitrous oxide as the oxidant. The isolated Fe sites at the surface of SBA-15can be attributed to tetrahedral Al sites providing cationic exchange properties at the SBA-15 surface. Owing to lower degree of agglomeration, Fe-Al-SBA-15 with lower Fe content exhibited better catalytic performance affording 40% phenol selectivity and a benzene conversion of 2.3% which was poorer than zeolite-based catalyst, FeZSM-5. The superior catalytic properties of FeZSM-5 may arise from its microporous environment which suppresses formation of overoxidized, bulkier reaction products [86]. Hydroxylation of phenol over highly ordered mesoporous Fe-Ga-SBA-15 materials prepared by hydrothermal synthesis procedure and in the presence of nitrous oxide as an oxidant was studied by Li and coworkers (2008). Fe-Ga-SBA-15 (0.03) showed 70% of phenol selectivity with almost 1.4% conversion of benzene. Over Ga-SBA-15 no conversion of phenol was observed, which clearly indicated that Fe is essential for benzene oxidation and that the presence of Ga leads to catalytically active Fe sites since in the absence of Ga the iron species were mainly coordinated in the amorphous silica walls while, in the presence of Ga (Fe–Ga–SBA-15), Fe species were distributed and isolated uniformly at the silica surface enhancing catalytic activity and selectivity. Furthermore, the researchers found that the Fe species in Fe–Ga–SBA-15 perform in a same manner of the FeZSM-5 zeolites and in comparison with Fe-Al-SBA-15, such a material exhibited higher selectivity toward phenol product [87]. Jourshabani et al. (2016), in a recent report, investigated FeNO3 supported on SBA-16 (Fe/SBA-16) by impregnation method for its capability to catalyze benzene hydroxylation to phenol using H2O2 as the oxidant. The influence of various parameters including reaction temperature, reaction time, amount of H2O2, and catalyst dosage on catalytic performance was also studied. It was found that under optimum condition, reaction temperature 65 °C, reaction time 8 h, H2O2 content 2 mL, and catalyst dosage 0.1 g, Fe/SBA-16 catalyst demonstrated higher catalytic activity of 11.7% phenol yield and a higher selectivity of 96.4% toward phenol product, which may have related to unique characteristics of mesoporous support including high surface area, large pore volume, and the three-dimensional connected channels, providing high mass transfer of benzene on the catalyst surface (Fig. 8 ) [88]. 3.4 Iron−Mesoporous C3N4 supported heterogeneous catalysts Zhang and coworkers (2013) discussed the photocatalytic activity of FeCl3 and mesoporous carbon nitride hybrid (FeCl3/mpg-C3N4) using H2O2 as an oxidant under visible light for the oxidation of benzene to phenol. The 5% FeCl3/mpg-C3N4 hybrid exhibited high catalytic activity with 38% benzene conversion and 97% phenol selectivity and turnover of frequency (TOF) was 56. When the oxidation of benzene by FeCl3/mpg-C3N4 hybrid was carried out in dark, a decrease to benzene conversion (9%) was observed, indicating the effect of visible light on accelerating of the oxidation reaction. In addition, by using FeCl3, g-C3N4 alone, the oxidation could not be occurred, revealing the synergistic impact of Fe species and mpg-C3N4 in this reaction. The authors suggested a mechanism that involves fast reduction of Fe+3 to Fe+2 by photo-irradiated electrons from FeCl3/mpg-C3N4 that can activate H2O2 to the key species (.OH radical followed by the oxidation of cyclohexadienyl radical produces phenol as the product (Fig. 9 ) [89]. 3.5 Iron−Mesoporous carbon supported heterogeneous catalysts In another study conducted by Cai et al. (2015), in order to investigate the impact of N incorporation in mesoporous carbon materials as support on catalytic performance, mesoporous carbon (MC), N-containing mesoporous carbon(N-MC) and mesoporous carbon with supported carbon nitride (C3N4 −MC) were used as support for immobilization of iron oxide. Among all catalysts, Fe/MC sample with 10 wt.% showed the highest catalytic activity with phenol yield of 10.9% in benzene hydroxylation using H2O2 as the oxidant, while no production of phenol was observed over Fe/N-MC materials. Poor catalytic properties of N-containing catalysts may arise from too fast decomposition of H2O2 along with over oxidation of benzene [90]. Cagelike mesoporous carbon was used by Sun et al. (2018) as the support to immobilize Fe(bpy)3(NO)3, an iron complex with N-atoms as anchors, via impregnation method. For the hydroxylation of benzene to phenol using H2O2 as the oxidant, at low temperature of 30 C, this heterogeneous catalyst with 1.26% Fe content exhibited 19.4% benzene conversion and phenol yield of 14.6%, which were higher than the catalyst without bipyridyl. It was found that in the case of catalyst with N anchors, the iron-based nanoparticles were isolated on the carbon matrix; while, most nanoparticles were aggregated on sample without bipyridyl [91]. 3.6 Iron−MNTs supported heterogeneous catalysts In 2006, the catalytic activity of the novel nanotubular iron phosphate with composite hierarchal meso‑macroporous structure (FeP-MNTs) in DHBP with hydrogen peroxide was compared with conventional mesoporous iron phosphate. The results indicated that the catalytic performance is sensitive to the morphology of the samples and the mesoporous nanotubes (FeP-MNTs) exhibited better catalytic activity for the reaction due to higher surface area which provides easier access to active sites. Moreover, strong interaction of the fluid molecules with the walls of the nanotubes leading to enhanced catalytic properties of the nanotubular iron phosphate sample [92]. 3.7 Iron−PMOs supported heterogeneous catalysts Gu and coworkers (2016) studied the introduction of three iron (III) complexes into periodic mesoporous organosilica (PMOs). The catalytic performance of the newly designed catalysts was investigated by the hydroxylation of benzene to phenol under mild condition with H2O2 as the oxidant (Fig. 10 ). In comparison with their iron (III) complexes, functionalizing of PMOs resulted in higher yield and selectivity of phenol. Due to the pore-structure, high surface area and the lipophilicity of PMOs, the bleaching of transition metal complexes has significantly decreased. As a result, benzene has tendency to retain in the pores while the product phenol which is less lipophilic than benzene ought to leave the pores and thus diffuses away from the catalytic centers, so using PMO-s catalytic systems involving transition metal complexes may be a tactic to promote the selectivity. With using 60 mg PMO-Fe and 15 mmol H2O2 for 12 h the better selectivity of 53.35% for production of phenol was achieved. Furthermore, heterogeneous PMOs catalysts show an excellent recyclability, making the introduced catalysts more benign from environmental and commercial viewpoint [93]. 3.8 Iron−HMS supported heterogeneous catalysts In 2016, amine-functionalized activated carbon (AC) and hexagonal mesoporous silica (HMS) were used as support for immobilization of VO(IV), Fe(II) and Fe(III) acetylacetonate complexes, as well as chloro‑[N, N′-bis(salicylaldehyde)- cyclohexanodiminate] iron(III) Schiff base complex [Fe(salhd)Cl]was also anchored onto these materials activated with a NaOH solution (Fig. 11 ). Liquid phase hydroxylation of benzene using H2O2 as the oxidant over these heterogeneous catalysts was compared with homogenous analogy by Carneiro et al. The immobilized [Fe(acac)2] and [Fe(acac)3] complexes exhibited better catalytic activity compared with the corresponding homogeneous ones, while the immobilized [VO(acac)2] complex and [Fe(salhd)Cl] complex onto HMS showed the same as benzene conversion as the homogenous phase reaction. The trend of the catalytic activity of these heterogeneous catalysts can be ordered as follows: [Fe(acac)2] APTES@HMS, [Fe(acac)2] APTES@AC > [Fe(salhd)]@HMS > [VO(acac)2]APTES@AC,[VO(acac)2]APTES@HM> [Fe(acac)3]APTES@AC. These results demonstrated that anchoring of a transition metal complex onto the surface of a porous support has a positive impact on catalytic conversion. Moreover, in the case of iron complexes, metal center tuning by incorporation of other coordination atoms in the organic ligand, such as nitrogen can make contribution to higher selectivity [94]. 4 Supported Cu-based catalysts Compounds of copper, owing to their rich abundance, environmentally-friendly properties and low price play an important role in the field of catalysis. 4.1 Copper−SBA supported heterogeneous catalysts A novel and simple direct method in an acid media has been introduced to prepare highly loaded CuO inside the channels of mesoporous hexagonal SBA-15 and cubic KIT-6 with almost 37 wt.% and 45 wt.% copper oxide content respectively. Comparison of the catalytic performance of these catalysts in liquid phase hydroxylation of benzene to phenol with the corresponding samples obtained from post-impregnated method demonstrated that the direct-synthesized mesoporous CuO/silica showed the higher catalytic property. High conversion of 20.6% and selectivity of 92.4% were achieved over CuO/SBA-15, while CuO/KIT-6 exhibited lower catalytic activity [95]. Highly loaded and well-dispersed CuO/SBA-15 with various Cu content (2.1–13.4 wt.%) was synthesized via a novel ultrasonic post-grafting method using trimethylchlorosilane (TMCS) and 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) as the modification surfactants and copper nitrate solution as the precursor. The highly dispersed CuO species and improved metal loading due to using the ultrasonic post-grafting method made the catalysts highly efficient in the benzene hydroxylation reaction in the presence of H2O2 as an oxidant. Under the employed reaction conditions, a maximum benzene conversion of 28% and a phenol selectivity of 95% were obtained over CuO/SBA-15 with 13.4 wt.% of copper [96]. 4.2 Copper−Mesoporous Tio2 supported heterogeneous catalysts Using hydrothermal method, Xu et al. (2013) discussed the catalytic activity of VOx‐TiO2 catalysts with different content of Cu as a second metal in the DHBP with hydrogen peroxide as the oxidant. The impact of several factors including Cu loading, interaction of Cu and vanadium oxide with TiO2 and calcination temperature on catalytic activity and selectivity for the DHBP were investigated. It was found that the addition of Cu as a second metal to VOx‐TiO2 enhanced the thermostability of the Cu/VOx‐TiO2 catalyst. Moreover, the monodispersion of the vanadium species on the carrier surface and the easy reduction of VOx at low temperatures were promoted. The interactions among the Cu species, V species, and TiO2 raised the binding energies of the Ti and V ions. High dispersion of isolated VOx and copper species was achieved with 0.75% of copper species loading. The Cu (0.75)/V (4.3) TiO2‐450 catalyst exhibited remarkable catalytic property for the benzene hydroxylation, with a phenol yield of 26% and phenol selectivity of 92% (Fig. 12 ) [97]. 4.3 Copper− mesoporous silica pillared clay supported heterogeneous catalysts Mesoporous silica pillared clay (MSPC) was employed as a new support to prepare Cu doped-MSPC catalyst via a facile process with a range of copper content (2.43–6.02%). Cu-MSPC with 4.16% copper loading showed the maximum catalytic activity in benzene hydroxylation reaction by using H2O2 as an oxidant and water as a solvent affording benzene conversion of 31.1% and selectivity of 96% toward phenol which was higher than the corresponding samples obtained from traditional impregnation method. This result revealed that there is a relation between the catalytic properties and the synthesis method and Cu-MSPCs catalyst has higher catalytic active sites in comparison with impregnated analogy, though the copper content is much less than the impregnated Cu/MSPC catalyst [98]. 4.4 Copper− mesoporous silica nanotube micro-reactor supported heterogeneous catalysts A series of hexagonal copper-doped multi-channel mesoporous silica nanotube micro-reactor (Cu-MNR) with various length including short, middle and long were synthesized through the adjustment of the molar ratio of CTAB and P123 as a dual surfactant in the presence of tetraamminecopper(II), Cu(NH3)4(NO3)2), as a copper source. With the increasing in the length of micro-reactors from 0.5, 1.0 to 1.5 μm, the benzene conversion enhanced and reached 33.9% over long one, while phenol selectivity remained the same (89%) indicating that the catalytic activities are sensitive to the length of micro-reactors. The authors attributed these results to the fact that increasing the length of micro-reactor provides effective absorbance of hydrophobic benzene molecule onto the hydrophilic inner channels of mesoporous silica by means of increasing the contact time of the reactant and the active sites inside (Fig. 13 ) [99]. 4.5 Copper− mesoporous KIT-6 supported heterogeneous catalysts Benzene was hydroxylated with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) in the presence of copper oxide doped mesoporous KIT-6 materials (CuO-KIT-6) prepared by ultrasonication impregnation procedure. The effects of operating parameters including solvent, catalyst amount, reaction time and temperature were examined on the catalytic performance. Three-dimensional, sheet like CuO-KIT-6 material obtained from 2 hours’ ultrasonication in acetonitrile medium exhibited the maximum benzene conversion of 32%. Since benzene hydroxylation is based on free OH. radical mechanism, and the CuO on the mesoporous KIT-6 material helps the formation of these radicals, CuO-KIT-6 (2 h ultrasonication) with high copper content showed the best benzene conversion [100]. 4.6 Copper− MCM-41 supported heterogeneous catalysts Yamada et al. investigated copper (II) complex ([Cu(tmpa)]2+ which tmpa = tris(2-pyridylmethyl) amine) incorporated into mesoporous silica-alumina (Al-MCM-41) by a cation exchange method for its capability to catalyze hydroxylation of benzene to phenol with H2O2. The authors suggested a radical chain mechanism in which HO2 • radical produced via the Fenton-like reduction of H2O2 with [Cu(tmpa)]2+ acts as the chain carrier radical. Spin trapping of the chain carrier radical resulted in the complete inhibition of the catalytic benzene hydroxylation. Prevention of hydroxylation of phenol and incorporation of the [Cu (tmpa)] 2+ into mesoporous silica-alumina providing better selectivity and durability of catalysts. The incorporated catalysts exhibited a high turnover number of 4320 and high selectivity of more than 99% toward phenol product [101]. 5 Supported Co-based catalysts 5.1 Cobalt− MCM supported heterogeneous catalysts Fe-MCM-41, Co-MCM-41 and Ni-MCM-41 heterogeneous catalysts prepared via hydrothermal procedure in liquid phase hydroxylation of benzene to phenol using H2O2 as the oxidant at 50 C. Among all prepared catalysts, Co-MCM-41 with 9.2% Co content showed the best catalytic activity affording 80.4% benzene conversion, which was also higher than that Co-MCM-41 obtained by impregnation method. Moreover, it was found that reaction factors such as, solvent, temperature and metal content have influence on catalytic properties of Co-incorporated catalysts. The adsorption capacity, activity and stability of the catalysts can be controlled by the metal kind and the metal content incorporated into mesoporous structure [102]. In another study conducted by Han et al., a series of Co-MCM-41with varying Co/Si ratios, which possess well-ordered long-range structures were synthesized via direct hydrothermal method using ascorbic acid as coreagent. The authors mentioned that the addition of ascorbic acid as auxiliary not only enhanced the ordering of mesoporous structure, but also increased the amount of incorporated cobalt atom which are important in catalytic applications of mesostructural molecular sieves. The highest benzene conversion of 35.4% and phenol selectivity of 100% was obtained over Co-MCM-41 with ratios of Co/Si 0.1 in reaction of benzene hydroxylation using H2O2 as the oxidant [103]. 5.2 Cobalt− SBA supported heterogeneous catalysts In another study conducted by Kalbasi et al. (2010), the surface of mesoporous silica SBA-15 was organofunctionalized by ethylendiaminopropyltrimethoxysilane (H2N–(CH2)2–NH–(CH2)3–), and then the amino groups of the mesoporous SBA-15 solids were used to coordinate two transition metals including Mn and Co (Mn, Co-G-SBA-15-NH). The obtained heterogeneous catalysts were employed to study the catalytic hydroxylation of benzene to phenol using H2O2 as oxidant in the presence of O2 atmosphere. The highest yield of 29% and 100% selectivity towards phenol product were obtained over Mn-amine-functionalized mesoporous silica SBA-15 catalyst, whereas under the same reaction conditions the Co catalyst exhibited lower catalytic performance. These results were explained by the higher BET surface area, larger pore volume and pore size of Mn-G-SBA-15-NH than the Co one. Moreover, it was mentioned that compared with methanol, acetonitrile and chloroform, solvent-free conditions are favorable for achieving the highest yield of phenol (Fig. 14 ) [40]. In 2013, Dong et al. investigated the liquid phase hydroxylation of benzene in acetic acid medium with H2O2 as the oxidant over a series of cobalt-doped SBA-16 (Co-SBA-16) mesoporous molecular sieves with various Co/Si ratio (0.04–0.2) prepared via evaporation induced self-assembly (EISA) method. The results showed that Co+2 species can be incorporated both in the framework sites and in the wall surface of well-ordered cubic cage like mesoporous SBA-16, while both of them act as active sites for the hydroxylation of benzene. Moreover, the authors reported that Co-SBA-16 obtained from EISA procedure exhibited higher catalytic activity than Co/SBA-15 and Co/SBA-16 synthesized by wet impregnation method. The first reason was attributed to the 3D cubic mesostructured of SBA-16 which favors better mass transportation compared with SBA-15 with 2D hexagonal mesostructured. The other is isolated Co(II) species in tetrahedral coordination shows more excellent catalytic activities than the crystalline Co3O4 species mainly located on the Co/SBA-16 and Co/SBA-15 catalysts. Co-SBA-16 with Co/Si ratios of 0.12 showed the high performance with the phenol yield of 28.8% and selectivity of 96.6%, yet poor stability in recycles [104]. 6 Supported Ti-based catalysts Several papers have been reported on the catalytic activity of Ti-based catalysts in direct oxidation of benzene to phenol. Moreover, owing to its proper optical features, high thermal and chemical stability, photocatalytic applications of Ti-based materials are extensively investigated that is far beyond the scope of this review[105]. 6.1 Titanium− MCM supported heterogeneous catalysts Catalytic performance of a series of mesoporous Ti-MCM-41 with different Si/Ti ratios (25–100) prepared by hydrothermal method were studied in liquid phase hydroxylation of benzene to phenol using H2O2 as the oxidant. Ti-MCM-41 containing 3.08 wt% titanium showed the highest benzene conversion of more than 70% and 100% selectivity toward phenol product, which was superior to corresponding sample obtained from impregnation method and Ti/NaY with the similar Ti content. This is due to the fact that titanium was found to adopt a tetrahedral coordination in hydrothermally synthesized samples providing well-dispersed Ti atoms, whereas; the catalysts prepared via impregnation method have large particle TiO2 in the pores. Moreover, the hydrophobicity of the MCM-41framework resulted in the high concentration of benzene as well as hindrance active sites blocking by water molecules leading to high catalytic activity of Ti-MCM-41[106]. In 2005, Lin et al. investigated the catalytic activity of silylated Ti-MCM-41 prepared via two synthetic methods including vapor phase silylation of Ti-MCM-41 and introduction of Ti to silylated MCM-41 via postsynthetic procedure. For hydroxylation of benzene using H2O2 as the oxidant, a series of silylated Ti-MCM-41 catalysts showed better catalytic properties than Ti-MCM-41 sample indicating that a simple silylation of Ti-MCM-41 can effectively increase catalytic activity and selectivity in oxidations. Moreover, the results showed that increasing the silylation time has a positive impact on catalytic performance and Ti-MCM-41 obtained from 9 h of vapor phase silylation gave the highest benzene conversion of 18.7% and 92.6% phenol selectivity. From 29Si MAS NMR spectral evidence, it appeared that vapor phase Ti-MCM-41 demonstrated a peak at 5.1 ppm assigned to the titanium species of (CH3)3SiOTi(OSi)3, providing new catalytically active titanium species, which leads to lower catalytic activity of conventional post-grafted silylated Ti-MCM-41 sample than that silylated for 5–9 h [107]. 7 Supported Cr and Mo-based catalysts 7.1 Chromium− SBA-16 supported heterogeneous catalysts Catalytic performance of chromium nitrate complex (Cr(NO3)3) immobilized on mesoporous silica SBA-16 by a simple impregnation method was studied in DHBP using H2O2 as the oxidant by Jourshabani and coworkers (2015). Different catalytic factors including reaction temperature, reaction time, amount of H2O2, and catalyst dosage were also optimized by RSM method. Cr-SBA-16 showed a high activity under optimized condition: reaction temperature 324 K, reaction time 8 h, H2O2 content 3.28 mL, and catalyst dosage 0.09 g and the yield of phenol was 9.05% and the selectivity to phenol was 100%. Moreover, the Cr/SBA-16 can be reused for four times without significant decrease in phenol yield or leaching during the reaction process. The reaction can be explained following mechanism based on dichromate species as active sites. According to which, in the first stage, biradical Cr-peroxo complex was formed and then Cr-peroxo complex was achieved by coordination of biradical Cr-peroxo with Cr in Cr/SBA-10 6. In the last step, a double bond in a benzene molecule was attacked by the open biradical form of the Cr–peroxo complex, so a biradical intermediate was produced which is stabilized by transformation to phenol (Fig. 15 ) [108]. 7.2 Molybdenum− FSM-16 supported heterogeneous catalysts Mesoporous silica FSM-16 was utilized as the support for grafting a series of mono- and polynuclear Mo complexes such as MoCl5, Mo2(OAc)4, [Mo3O(CCH3)(OAc)6(MeOH)3]Cl, and [RhCp*MoO4]4 by Zama et al. (2000). The catalytic activity of these heterogeneous catalysts was tested in the hydroxylation of benzene using H2O2 as the oxidant under the irradiation of UV-light. Among all these catalysts, trinuclear Mo oxo complex/FSM-16 showed the highest catalytic activity affording TON of 433 in 6 h and the ratio of phenol/biphenyl of 82/18, which was significantly higher than did the homogenous catalyst. The enhanced catalytic performance of Mo3/FSM-16 was ascribed to the Fenton-type mechanism [109]. 8 Conclusion From the point of view of industry, pharmaceuticals and chemical products, phenol is an important product. In industry, phenol is mainly produced by the three-step indirect, cumene energy consuming process, while the direct oxidation step of benzene to phenol is the most economical route. In the past decade, great progress has been made in the design of new heterogeneous catalysts for DHBP. Many of these endeavors is based on the incorporation and immobilization of transition metal species into mesoporous supports. In this review, we focused on the development of introducing novel, selective heterogeneous catalysts for direct benzene hydroxylation to phenol. Because of high surface areas, large pore sizes and volumes, short diffusion reaction pathways and modifiable surfaces, mesoporous materials can provide unique and special advantages for both catalyst and catalyst support application. Moreover, modification of mesoporous supports with transition metal complexes has remarkable benefits including the improvement of selectivity, catalytic activity, oxidant efficiency and reusability. It is the authors hope that the concepts described in this paper inspire other researches in this area to initiate new discoveries. coredata.dc:description: This review provides an outlook on heterogeneous catalysts for direct hydroxylation of benzene to phenol (DHBP) with a special focus on various mesoporous transition metal-based catalysts. Among all molecular sieves, mesoporous materials with high surface area and pore volume, tuneable pore sizes, and rich morphology can serve as both efficient catalytic supports and catalysts. The modification of meso‑pores with transition metal species provides the materials with great properties, making the catalysis process highly selective and controllable. This emerging area can provide researchers with great opportunity to introduce novel heterogeneous catalysts from both industrial and environmentally friendly viewpoints.
coredata.dc:title: Review of some transition metal-based mesoporous catalysts for the direct hydroxylation of benzene to phenol (DHBP)
